p: The simplest aromatic aldehyde, benzaldehyde 17, is probably one of the most frequently used natural flavouring substance and is second only to vanillin 1, which is also an aldehyde, but in most cases its synthetic equivalent is used instead of a natural compound ( Figure 5). They are influenced by economic considerations. Benzaldehyde can be obtained from a variety of natural sources, including fruit stones or by chemical synthesis. The content of benzaldehyde in apricot fruit stone is ca. 1.2%. This material is a main source of natural benzaldehyde [ 52]. Due to the intense aroma of almonds, it is used to flavour cakes, fruit juices, soft drinks, hard and soft candies and chewing gums. In some cases this compound is applied as a flavour enhancer in beers. It is also included in many food fragrances, e.g., cherry and almond [ 58]. Benzaldehyde found an application as a repellent for driving bees to get them away from a honeycomb [ 59].
